docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Kenneth J. Ryan, a Harvard obstetrician who helped the nation grapple with thorny ethical issues like fetal tissue research, died on Jan. 5 at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 75. The cause was a heart attack, his family said.

headline.main: Kenneth Ryan, 75, Obstetrician and Leader in Medical Ethics

docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth J Ryan, Harvard obstetrician who helped nation grapple with issues such as fetal tissue research, dies at age 75 (S)
docs.snippet: Dr. Kenneth J. Ryan, a Harvard obstetrician who helped the nation grapple with thorny ethical issues like fetal tissue research, died on Jan. 5 at his home in Weston, Mass.  He was 75.    The cause was a heart attack, his family said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Natasha Caines felt overwhelmed. The part-time job she had recently begun was not what she had expected. Her welfare checks had stopped coming. Her apartment was flooded with toilet water from an apartment above. Her electricity was about to be cut off. And she was months behind on her rent. Such was Ms. Caines's life about a year ago, with her third child, Chyna Blair, due in four months and her two other children going hungry.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Return From the Brink of Surrender

docs.abstract: Community Service Society of New York, which receives support from New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, helps young mother pay rent so she and her children are not evicted from their apartment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sufiyatu Huseini sits on the earth floor of a tiny mud hut breast-feeding her 10-month-old daughter, Adama, and occasionally waving away flies that swarm around the child's eyes and mouth. She says she is 35, but her wizened face and broken brown teeth make her look considerably older. This ordinary woman, as poor as any in this impoverished region of northern Nigeria, recently became horribly extraordinary: last June, an Islamic court in Sokoto, the regional capital, sentenced her to death by stoning for committing adultery. The evidence is the child she now feeds. The judge mandated that the sentence be carried out as soon as Adama is weaned. Sufiya, as the woman is known, has appealed the judgment, and a hearing is scheduled for the middle of March. But there is a good chance that the appeal will not save her. The recent introduction of the full sharia -- strict Islamic rule of law backed up by harsh punishments -- in 10 of Nigeria's 12 northern states is a highly political issue in the region, whose population is largely Islamic and whose courts are strongly influenced by the militant Islamists who have come to wield significant power.
docs.abstract: Richard Dowden article on workings of Islamic law in northern Nigeria focuses on case of Sufiyatu Huseini, who faces stoning for adultery; Huseini divorced husband because he could not support her, returned to live with her father and became pregnant when raped by man who seeks to marry her; pregnancy, considered proof of her adultery under strictest interpretation of Koran in force in her region, has delayed her execution until child is weaned; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood has filed a federal lawsuit challenging a state law that abortions after 12 weeks of pregnancy must be performed in hospitals. Planned Parenthood, which operates clinics in Sioux Falls and Rapid City, said the 1973 law relied on old standards regarding what medical resources should be required at what point in pregnancy. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Challenge To Abortion Law

docs.lead_paragraph: Using a portable device to monitor contractions in pregnant women does not help detect early labor and prevent premature delivery, a study has found. The research suggests that other screening tests for premature labor do not work very well, either. Premature birth is a leading cause of death and disability for newborns. Doctors try to detect premature labor early enough to delay it so the fetus can develop fully.

headline.main: Prenatal Device Found to Offer Little Help On Early Labor

docs.abstract: Study finds using portable device to monitor contractions in pregnant women does not help detect early labor and prevent premature delivery; finds only slight difference in number of contractions for women who delivered prematurely and those who did not, suggesting other screening tests for premature labor also do not work very well (M)
docs.snippet: Using a portable device to monitor contractions in pregnant women does not help detect early labor and prevent premature delivery, a study has found. The research suggests that other screening tests for premature labor do not work very well, either. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nevirapine, a drug that reduces the chance that an H.I.V.-positive pregnant woman will transmit the virus to her child, is to be made available in public hospitals in KwaZulu/Natal, South Africa's most AIDS-stricken province, an official said. The government says the drug's safety remains unproven and restricts its use to a few pilot sites. But KwaZulu/Natal is controlled by the Zulu nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party, which has apparently decided to override government restrictions.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Easier Access To Aids Drug

docs.abstract: KwaZulu/Natal, South Africa, to make Nevirapine, drug that reduces chance HIV-positive pregnant women will transmit virus to child, available in public hospitals; national government holds drug's safety remains unproven and restricts its use (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Can an acne drug cause teenagers to commit suicide? The question returned to the spotlight this month when a 15-year-old boy flew a small airplane into a Florida skyscraper. The boy, Charles J. Bishop, an unlicensed pilot, had a prescription for Accutane, which has been associated with suicide enough to cause the Food and Drug Administration to require a special warning label. Toxicology tests by the county medical examiner found no Accutane in Mr. Bishop's system at the time of his death. But that finding may not end questions about whether the drug influenced the youth's behavior. Some think Accutane may affect mood weeks or months after a patient stops taking it. It certainly will not end a 20-year debate over how strictly this potent but potentially dangerous drug should be regulated.

headline.main: Debate on Acne Drug's Safety Persists Over Two Decades

docs.abstract: Suicide flight by Charles J Bishop, 15, who had prescription for Accutane, into Florida skyscraper spurs renewed debate over how closely potent acne treatment should be regulated because of its links to suicides; some think drug may affect mood weeks or months after patient stops taking it; studies indicate teenagers who take drug are no more likely to attempt suicide than those who do not (M)
